skill.name: pydeseq2
skill.description: Differential gene expression analysis (Python DESeq2). Identify DE genes from bulk RNA-seq counts, Wald tests, FDR correction, volcano/MA plots, for RNA-seq analysis.
skill.summary: Differential gene expression analysis (Python DESeq2). Identify DE genes from bulk RNA-seq counts, W...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: All static analysis findings are false positives. The 'weak cryptographic algorithm' findings incorrectly flag 'DESeq2' (a statistical method) as cryptography. The 'external_commands' findings misinterpret Python code blocks as shell commands. No actual security risks detected.

content.user_title: Analyze RNA-seq data with PyDESeq2 differential expression
content.value_statement: PyDESeq2 enables differential gene expression analysis from bulk RNA-seq count data. Perform statistical testing, multiple comparison correction, and generate publication-ready visualizations.
actual_capabilities: Load and validate RNA-seq count matrices from CSV/TSV files
Perform DESeq2 normalization and dispersion fitting
Execute Wald tests for differential expression
Export results as CSV and pickle files
limitations: Requires samples Ã— genes orientation for count matrices
Minimum 10 total counts per gene recommended
Designed for bulk RNA-seq, not single-cell data

use_cases.title: Compare treated vs control samples
use_cases.description: Identify differentially expressed genes between experimental conditions with proper statistical testing and multiple testing correction.

use_cases.title: Analyze RNA-seq dataset for thesis
use_cases.description: Process count data from RNA-seq experiment, perform quality control, and generate publication-ready figures for thesis or paper.

use_cases.title: Batch process multiple RNA-seq datasets
use_cases.description: Automate differential expression analysis across multiple conditions or timepoints using the command-line script.

prompt_templates.title: Basic DE analysis
prompt_templates.scenario: User has counts.csv and metadata.csv files
prompt_templates.prompt: Load my RNA-seq data from counts.csv and metadata.csv, perform differential expression analysis comparing treated vs control samples using PyDESeq2

prompt_templates.title: Multi-factor design
prompt_templates.scenario: User needs to control for batch effects
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze my RNA-seq data accounting for batch effects using design formula ~batch + condition, then test for treatment vs control differences

prompt_templates.title: Generate plots
prompt_templates.prompt: Run PyDESeq2 analysis on my data and create volcano and MA plots highlighting significant genes (padj < 0.05)

prompt_templates.title: Advanced filtering
prompt_templates.prompt: Load RNA-seq data, filter genes with < 20 total counts, use multi-factor design ~age + sex + condition, and identify genes with |log2FC| > 1 and padj < 0.01

output_examples.input: Analyze my RNA-seq data and show top 10 differentially expressed genes

best_practices: Always transpose count matrix if genes are rows (use .T)
Filter low-count genes before analysis to improve power
Check that sample names match between counts and metadata
Use adjusted p-values (padj) not raw p-values for significance
anti_patterns: Don't use raw p-values for multiple testing - always use FDR-corrected padj
Never transpose metadata - only transpose the count matrix if needed
Avoid complex designs without sufficient sample size per condition
Don't apply LFC shrinkage before statistical testing

faq.question: Why do I get 'Index mismatch' error?
faq.answer: Sample names in counts and metadata don't match. Check both files use identical sample identifiers.

faq.question: Should I transpose my count matrix?
faq.answer: If your CSV has genes as rows and samples as columns, use .T to transpose to samples Ã— genes format.

faq.question: What's the difference between pvalue and padj?
faq.answer: pvalue is raw p-value; padj is FDR-corrected for multiple testing. Use padj < 0.05 for significance.

faq.question: When should I use LFC shrinkage?
faq.answer: Apply after statistical testing for visualization, ranking genes, or creating heatmaps. Don't use for significance testing.

faq.question: How do I handle batch effects?
faq.answer: Include batch in design formula: ~batch + condition. This controls for technical variation while testing biological differences.

faq.question: Why are no genes significant?
faq.answer: Check sample size, effect sizes, and variability. Small studies or subtle effects may yield few significant genes.
